verses.text: When the enemies of Judah and Benjamin heard that the exiles were rebuilding a temple to the LORD, the God of Israel,
verses.comment: The term 'enemies' here refers to local peoples who opposed the returnees. Note the emphasis on the LORD as the God of Israel.

verses.text: they approached Zerubbabel and the heads of the fathers’ houses and said to them, 'Let us build with you, for we seek your God as you do, and we have been sacrificing to him since the days of Esarhaddon king of Assyria who brought us here.'
verses.comment: The offer to help is deceptive; these people practiced syncretism—worshiping both the God of Israel and other gods. See also 2 Kings 17:29-33.

verses.text: But Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the rest of the heads of Israel’s families said to them, 'You have nothing to do with us in building a house to our God; but we alone will build to the LORD, the God of Israel, as King Cyrus the king of Persia has commanded us.'
verses.comment: They insist on the purity of worship and fulfillment of the king's decree. This foreshadows the New Testament emphasis on the true worship of God in unity.

verses.text: Then the people of the land discouraged the people of Judah and frightened them from building.
verses.comment: Opposition to the faithful is a recurring biblical theme. The faithful must persevere in the face of adversity (see Neh. 4:8-9).

verses.text: They bribed counselors against them to frustrate their plans all the days of Cyrus king of Persia, even until the reign of Darius king of Persia.
verses.comment: The opposition continues through successive reigns, showing the resilience of the returned exiles. There is a foreshadowing here of the importance of God's providence.

verses.text: In the reign of Ahasuerus, at the beginning of his reign, they wrote an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Ahasuerus is likely Xerxes I. The pattern of writing accusations against God's people occurs throughout history (cf. Rev. 12:10).

verses.text: And in the days of Artaxerxes, Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel and the rest of their associates wrote to Artaxerxes king of Persia. The letter was written in Aramaic script and translated into the Aramaic language.
verses.comment: The narrative now shifts to Aramaic, the international language of the Persian Empire (see also Dan. 2:4b).

verses.text: Rehum the commander and Shimshai the scribe wrote a letter against Jerusalem to King Artaxerxes as follows—
verses.comment: This section contains a preserved copy of the official correspondence. The Aramaic language marks an administrative shift.

verses.text: 'Rehum the commander, Shimshai the scribe, and the rest of their colleagues—the judges, the officials, the Persians, the men of Erech, the Babylonians, the men of Susa (that is, the Elamites),
verses.comment: The officials represent various peoples relocated by former empires, reflecting the diversity and power of the Persian administration.

verses.text: and the rest of the nations whom the great and honorable Osnappar deported and settled in the cities of Samaria, and in the rest of the province Beyond the River.'
verses.comment: 'Osnappar' likely refers to Ashurbanipal. 'Beyond the River' describes the Persian province west of the Euphrates.

verses.text: This is a copy of the letter they sent: 'To King Artaxerxes. Your servants, the men of the province Beyond the River, and so forth.'
verses.comment: An official but formulaic opening, characteristic of Persian correspondence.

verses.text: Let it be known to the king that the Jews who came up from you to us have arrived at Jerusalem and are rebuilding that rebellious and wicked city. They are completing the walls and repairing the foundations.
verses.comment: The opponents slander the Jews by calling Jerusalem rebellious, typical language to provoke imperial concern.

verses.text: Now be it known to the king that if this city is rebuilt and the walls are completed, they will not pay tribute, tax, or toll, and the royal revenue will suffer.
verses.comment: The letter appeals to the king’s concern for imperial revenues. This is a political rather than religious accusation.

verses.text: Now because we eat the salt of the palace and it is not fitting for us to see the king dishonored, we send and inform the king,
verses.comment: 'Eat the salt of the palace' is a metaphor for loyalty to the king, denoting privilege and obligation.

verses.text: so that a search may be made in the record books of your fathers. In the record books you will find and learn that this city is a rebellious city, harmful to kings and provinces, and that sedition has been stirred up in it from ancient times. That is why this city was destroyed.
verses.comment: Jerusalem's history of rebellion is referenced, a half-truth influencing the king. The call to search official records emphasizes legalism.

verses.text: We make known to the king that if this city is rebuilt and its walls completed, by this means you will have no portion in the province Beyond the River.'
verses.comment: They exaggerate the threat, fearing loss of territory and influence. The motif of Jerusalem's walls symbolizes stability and defense.

verses.text: The king sent an answer: 'To Rehum the commander, Shimshai the scribe, and the rest of their colleagues who live in Samaria, and the rest of the province Beyond the River: Peace.'
verses.comment: The king’s reply mirrors typical Aramaic formulae—'peace' or 'shalom,' a greeting with deep spiritual undertones throughout the Bible.

verses.text: 'The letter you sent to us has been plainly read before me.'
verses.comment: A simple acknowledgement of receiving and reading their letter.

verses.text: 'I issued a decree, and search has been made, and it is found that this city from of old has risen against kings, and rebellion and sedition have been made in it.'
verses.comment: The king’s independent verification underscores the legal process, even when it is unjust.

verses.text: 'Powerful kings have ruled over Jerusalem, governing all the province Beyond the River, and tribute, tax, and toll were paid to them.'
verses.comment: Reference to Jerusalem’s former imperial influence, echoing Israel’s glory under David and Solomon.

verses.text: 'Therefore, give an order for these men to stop, so that this city is not rebuilt until a decree is issued by me.'
verses.comment: Temple work's suspension highlights the saints' perseverance during periods when God’s plan is hidden but ultimately victorious.

verses.text: 'Be careful not to be negligent in doing this. Why should damage grow to the hurt of the kings?'
verses.comment: Imperial authority is concerned with order. The vigilance demanded here is reflected in the epistles' calls for Christians to be alert (cf. 1 Pet. 5:8).

verses.text: Then, as soon as the copy of the letter from King Artaxerxes was read before Rehum, Shimshai the scribe, and their associates, they went in haste to the Jews in Jerusalem and forced them to stop by power and force.
verses.comment: The cessation of work under compulsion underscores the consistent experience of God’s people enduring setbacks before triumph.

verses.text: Thus the work on the house of God in Jerusalem stopped, and it remained halted until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia.
verses.comment: The work on God’s house, though halted, will be restored in God’s providential timing. The theme of overcoming obstacles appears throughout salvation history (see Matt. 16:18; Rev. 21:2).
